{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3332299,"name":"Nolan Locke","username":"NolanL","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nolanl/{size}/224254_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T19:49:31.408Z","cooked":"

We have two cameras for driver vision on our robot, and want to be able to switch between them during the match to save bandwidth. Both cameras are plugged into a usb hub which is in one of the ports on the rio. I found some older examples here on how to do it, but I was wondering if anyone had something more recent? After trying yesterday, we had constant loop overruns and issues with usb bandwith.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-03-13T19:49:31.408Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":148.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458565,"topic_slug":"switchable-camera","display_username":"Nolan Locke","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 8-Bit (not 8-Bit) | 9432"},"post_url":"/t/switchable-camera/458565/1","custom_user_title":"Team 8-Bit (not 8-Bit) | 9432","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3332440,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-13T21:52:05.924Z","cooked":"

Issues with USB bandwidth is going to be a challenge on the Rio–essentially the problem is that for fast changes between camera feeds, you want both cameras connected and streaming, and only switch which one is sent over the network. This requires 2x cameras worth of USB bandwidth. If you can live with “slow” switching (1-2 seconds on switch), essentially 1 camera would disconnect, then the other camera can connect, lowering the USB bandwidth to just 1 camera.

In addition, camera streaming takes a decent amount of CPU, particularly if you have to use software scaling / recompression to fit within the available bandwidth. The software will try to use the JPEG stream directly from the camera if possible, but setting a custom resolution or compression ratio requires a bunch of additional software steps (decompression, scaling, recompression) which will increase latency and be a major CPU hit.

For these reasons, I would highly recommend you look at acquiring/using a Raspberry Pi (you don’t need a 5; a 3b or 4 will work fine for this purpose) and connecting the cameras to it instead of using the Rio for this task. The WPILibPi image makes this very easy to do, including configuring switchable cameras (controlled by a NT value) via its web UI.

I see. Do you have any examples for the “slow” switching? I think that would be fine for our purposes. We are competing this weekend, so we won’t have time to setup the pi right now, but that is something that we can do for our competition next weekend. The scaling thing is also a good tip, I’ll have to see if we can stream it without changing the resolution. Thanks!

At 2495 we have been using WPILibPi with the NetworkTable-selectable switched camera support since Peter released it back in 2019 WPILib FRCVision Raspberry Pi image 2019.3.1 Update - Technical / Programming - Chief Delphi

It’s just great, and I would like to thank you again Peter for having implemented it so quickly at the time.

If you ever decide to use it, you can use this class to remotely switch the virtual camera to whatever physical camera you want: FRC2495-2024/src/main/java/frc/robot/sensors/SwitchedCamera.java at main · FRC2495/FRC2495-2024 (github.com)

It’s a bit of a hack, as it’s not built into the library to do this, but essentially the approach is to follow the second example in the docs, but add a bit of sequencing: setSource(null), delay (a few hundred ms? you probably will need to play around with how long), setSource(selected camera). As with any delay in periodic code, it has to be implemented with a Timer or Command delay, not just a sleep.
